Name: Bio-SNEAKERS
Description:
Bio-SNEAKERS is a multiplayer card game. Mankind has been subjugated by machines and the planet is ruled by an all controlling AI (artificial Intelligence) The object is to to hack the ruling AI and destroy all its core mainframes. If even one of the mainframes survives then all the players lose. 
There are various ways of hacking the mainframes and doing it stealthily will give you control points. If you have the most control points at the end of the game then you will control the machines and rule.
The rules are only one page in length. 
There are 9 pages of components required for the full 5 player game but only 5 pages of components are required for a 2 player game.

Name: Das Konzil
Description:
It's about money, trade, wine, salt, grain, profit, buying and selling, time, sins, plague, witches, murderers, beggars, inquisitors, Knight ........

The aim of the council is to appoint a new Pope.  Anyone who has at the end of the game on the most electors, may name the new pope and is the winner of the game.

---

Es geht um Geld, Handel, Wein, Salz, Getreide, Gewinn, Kauf- und Verkauf, Zeit, Sünden, Pest, Hexen, Mörder, Bettler, Inquisitoren, Ritter........
Ziel des Konzils ist,einen neuen Papst zu benennen. Wer am Ende des Spiels über die meisten Wahlmänner verfügt, darf den neuen Papst benennen und ist Sieger des Spiels.

Name: OSKI
Description:
OSKI is simple word game for two players. Game can be played as paper and pencil game - no tiles are required. Game can be played almost in any language.

Game is played on hexagonal board with 19 fields. Initial word has three letters and is written into central three fields. Player on move create some word from existed letters and from new letter added to board. Player score according to length of word. Player with higher score win game.

Name: Wend-loop
Description:
The meandering path game.

Wend-loop is a path building game for two or more players. Players place tiles to build paths, and move their pieces along paths, sometimes jumping onto another path. The object of the game is to score the most points by completing paths containing your piece.

Contents
4 Player pieces
A set of 35 Playing tiles

Wend tiles are square in shape, and have 2 path entry/exit points on each edge. They each have four path sections which go from one path entry/exit point to another. When placed side by side, the path sections from one tile join up with those on the adjacent tile, to create meandering paths. There are 35 Wend tiles in a set, which includes one copy of all possible different combinations of 4 path sections on a tile.

A single set of 35 Wend tiles is enough for a good game with 2-4 players. You can use extra sets of Wend tiles to accommodate more players or for a longer and more challenging game with a small number of players.

Name: Parkany 1683
Description:
Published in first issue of Dragon Hobby magazine.

The expansion provides new map with four scenarios and two new commander tokens (Thokoly and Mehmed whose statistics are changed as compared to WiedeÅ„ 1683).

There are only minor changes in the rules mostly covering charges. The changes make the game more dynamic than original WiedeÅ„ 1683.

Name: Shootin' Baskets
Description: A dexterity game in the same vein as Mr. Mouth. A basketball backboard with baskets on both sides is placed in the middle of a turntable. While the backboard spins around, up to four players try to launch balls into the baskets using small catapults. The first player to get all six of their balls into the baskets is the winner.

Name: Mauseschlau&Bärenstark: Weltreise
Description:
The children's game Mauseschlau&Bärenstark: Weltreise features the lovable cartoon characters in a race around the world. The mouse and bear answer questions about geography, culture, flags, landmarks, and much more!

The whimsical spinner has two sides: one with pictures and another with text. The game is designed to be enjoyed by kids of all ages with different play levels.

Name: Disney Memorix
Description:
from the rule book

Contenent: 16 large cards; 16 small cards; 16counter; 
1 playing piece; 1 die.

Object of the game:
Players need to find the hidden Disney friends and collect counters to win the game.

How to play:
Place the large cards with the illustrated side face up to form a square. Place the small cards so they are also face up in the middle of the square.
The first player start throwing the die and move the playing piece around the large card in a clockwise direction. The Disney character you land on indicate the small card you must turn over in the middle. This ends the turn.
When you land on a large card that has alredy had the matching small card turned face down, you have to remember where this card is and find it. If you find it, you may take a counter, the first player to collect 4 counter win.

Name: Tornado Alert!
Description:
From the back of the game box:

Calling all fearless photographers!
We are today heading for Oklahoma City where the first ever Tornado Spotting  World Championships are about to begin. Extreme weather is expected, accompanied by even more extreme photographers. Speed, split-second timing, calculated risk-taking and outsmarting the competition are your tickets to victory!

Original version: Object of the game from the first page of rulebook:

The players compete for three rounds then see who, on average, has taken the best tornado photos. The higher the number of points from the photos, the better. The higher the number of card, the more dangerous the photographer's location depicted, so it's important to make the right decisions during the game. At the end of each round, the players determine their average score of the photos taken in their points pile using the averages table. Each round ends when the Game Over card is picked up. After the third round, each player's lowest average score of the three is selected and the player with the highest of these lowest scores is the winner.

Second Edition changes game as follows:

Players no more try to get highest average during three rounds. Instead, they try to get as much points as possible during each round and players can play any number of rounds as well. This makes averages table obsolete in second edition. Some card functions are also streamlined to make game play faster and more intuitive. Rules of the second edition are only in english and finnish.

The game box contains:

75 cards (21 different types of)
15 +1/-1 markers
1 two-sided score table
1 score pad (50 pages)
Includes German, French, English, Dutch, Swedish and Finnish rules.

Name: Barney's Rainbow Egg Game
Description:
This is a children's game based on the Barney's Great Adventure movie.

Players leave the barn with Twinken's Rainbow Egg and move along the track by matching colors. The kids have adventures as they visit the circus, watch a parade, etc. Cards instruct the children to find colors or play let's pretend.

Players collect star chips for following instructions correctly. The kid with the most score chips when the players reach the finish line is declared the winner.
 Includes a colorful puzzle-cut board, a plastic Barney, the egg, star tokens, a spinner, cards, and the rules.

Name: Shed
Description: Shed is a clever trick-taking game for 2-5 players that fully utilizes all of the unique characteristics of the Decktet Game System. Players start the game with a pool of tokens matching the Decktet’s suits and then they try to get rid of them through careful trick taking. The first player to shed all of his tokens is the winner.

Name: Run Mousey Run
Description:
Description from box:

The little mouse who's hungry for cheese
Must avoid the cat and the old lady's broom
Help him to escape through the mousehole with ease,
Or win all the cheese that's there in the room.

User Summary:
The mouse is pulled back and wound up, then released from the center circle. Where will he land? Will you win 1-4 pieces of cheese (get 8 on your cheese board and you win!) or will you get the broom or the cat? If the mouse gets out through the mouse hole past the cat you win automatically.

Name: Color-Coded
Description:
In this color decoding, star gathering, trick playing game you gotta be the first to match your various colored Star Cards with the Code dealt and use special PLAY cards, switch abilities and Black Wild cards to change the round in your favor. Obtain five wins and the game is yours!

Color-Coded is simple to learn! Each player is given a specific code of colored stars they need to match using the colored cards in their hand. Match the code and you move on to the next, match five and you win the game!

There are special cards to help tip the balance in your favor. Use the Black Wild Cards which can be used for any card in your code. PLAY cards grant abilities like switching, trading, and even destroying your other players hand and code! When nothing else can be done, you can at least tempt fate by using SWITCH, which forces all players to choose a card from their hands and pass it to their left, maybe the card you need is just around the corner?

The best part is no matter where you are in the game, additional people can join in the fun! Simply deal then a hand and give him a code. Who knows, the winner may have just arrived!


     of Players: 2-6


Game Time: 45 min.

Includes:
    * Star Cards Deck (80 cards)
    * Code Cards Deck (40 cards)
    * Color-Coded Rules Document

Name: ASL Annual '95
Description:
An extra large magazine/supplement to make up for the 'year without ASL' (1994), containing articles and scenarios. It came with an outer cardstock cover that had overlays for Deluxe ASL; however, these turned out to be printed at the wrong size


( from the Table of Contents:)

Airborne Samurai by Steven C. Swann
Annual Crossfire by Robert Banozic & Mark Nixon
Warriors All! by David Payne
The Chestnuts of Normandy by Jim Stahler
En Garde by Chuck Goetz
The Gentle Art of Routing by Steve Tinsley
The Scenarios of Normandy by Jim Stahler
Series Replay: Festung St. Edouard by Steve Peterson, Brian Youse & Chuck Goetz

Scenarios:
A68 Acts of Defiance
A69 Broich Bash
A70 Wintergewitter
A71 Patton's Prayers
A72 Italian Brothers
A73 Not Out of the Woods Yet
A74 Valhalla Bound
A75 Medal of Honor
A76 Night Drop
A77 Hide & Seek
A78 Prelude to Breakout
A79 Mike Red
A80 Commando Schenke
A81 They Fired on Odessa...
A82 Orange at Walawbum
A83 Last of Their Strength
A84 Endless Struggle
A85 Airborne Samurai
A86 Fighting Sparrow
A87 The Grand Canal
A88 Surprise Encounter
A89 First Day of Diadem
A90 Cutting Out a Strongpoint
DA13 The Mailed Fist

Name: De Twaalfde Man
Description:
De Twaalfde Man is a simple roll-and-move game. It was given away at EMTÉ Supermarkets (The Netherlands) for the 2010 World Cup.

The game recuires 1 die and a miniature from 'Het Oranje Legioen' per player. 'Het Oranje Legioen' are small, orange supporters you can collect at the supermarket.

The board is a soccerpitch on which players move their pawn. On different fields a special situation happens - always with a soccer background: a yellow card, an off-side, free kick, etc. The winner is the one who - on the last field - kicks the ball in the right corner (by throwing the die).

Name: The Ancient Magnetic travel set
Description:
From the box top,

Contains all that is needed to play Ancient Wargames on the move!, 
set includes: Rules, Magnetic playing surface and terrain,
              Dice, 
              Two measures & 
              Two painted and magnetised armies!!

User:

Players compete with two preselected ancients armies to be the first to out fight their opponent by destroying four enemy units whilst losing less of their own units. Each player has a camp which counts as two units if captured and a general who is equivalent to four units.

The scenery is fully magnetic and offers a myriad of battlefields. Scenery includes river, hills and rough terrain, all of which greatly affect unit capabilities.

The two painted ~2mm scale armies offer varying units including; cavalry, knights (including chariots), elephants, archers, pike and psiloi.

This original version includes Alma Wargames Easy-peasey Ancient Wargames Rules a simplified derivative of De Bellis Antiquitatis 1.2 and offer rules for flanking and unit depth.

All units and scenery are magnetic and battle is joined within the box which has a green battle area with magnetic storage.

This is truly a travel miniatures wargame which can be played on the move.

Name: Shuffle Shot
Description:
From the box: "Shuffle Shot is the origional pro tabletop shuffleboard game."

Over a series of turns players either individually or in teams glides weights across the board into a scoring field incremented at 1, 2, and 3 points trying to earn the most points without going off the board. Rules include several scoring variations.

Name: Naktong Bulge: Breaking the Perimeter
Description:
From the Decision Games' website:

By August 1950 the North Korean Army had overrun most of the Korean peninsula, and was advancing rapidly toward Pusan, the last open port in South Korea.

The US Army hastily formed a perimeter along the arcing Naktong River to stop — or at least delay — the final North Korean breakthrough. Every available US unit in Korea, including a Marine brigade, was thrown into the fight against three North Korean infantry divisions converging to crush what became known as the "Naktong Bulge."

Naktong Bulge utilizes the new Fire & Movement combat system that's designed so players can augment their units with "support fire" during the course of the turn. From fighter -bombers to artillery, units can receive support to engage enemy positions and formations, allowing combat to develop at all levels. A single recon company, for example — perhaps supported by howitzers — could be tasked to assault a lone enemy infantry battalion defending a mountain pass. As its attack gets underway, however, the recon company may find itself under fire from heavy artillery. More support will be necessary to take the pass, but assets are limited.

In Naktong Bulge the attritional design of the new Combat Results Table simulates the true nature of combat during the Korean War. Units are typically two-sided formations that can incur casualties, accurately replicating the realities of combat and the high losses sustained by both sides during the Korean War. Winning the battle is thus a matter of maneuver, firepower and asset management.
Families: Series: Fire & Movement combat system (Decision Games)

Name: Swordplay: Generic skirmish rules
Description:
Front Cover:

Brawls from the dawn of time until the age of black powder.

Inside the rulebook.

"Swordplay" is a set of rules. Written to provide a universal set of skirmish rules, from the dawn of man up to the beginnin of black powder weapons. It covers the sword and sharp pointy stick type of warfare best.
At the end of the book are provided some historical period details to get you started. It is planned to provide details for other periods at a later date.
The rules are written to provide a more "Hollywood" type of game rather than historical accuracy. So if you were brought up on a diet of swashbuckling heroes, and dastardly villains these are the rules for you.

User,

Exhaustive individual character skirmish rules including horses. Includes scenarios for Maldon 991 C.E. (Viking vs Saxon), Ambush Wars of the Roses 1461 C.E. and Bar Room Brawl France 1627 C.E.

Name: Swordplay Supplement: The Three Musketeers
Description:
Front Cover;

Recreate the cut and thrust of this classic tale. All the characters and scenarios listed for "Swordplay" rules. Including rules for large groups and mass actions.

User;

Includes eight new scenarios including new rules for grenades and the "A Cast of Thousands" group rules.

Full of flavour this game allows you to recreate a blend of the classic novel with the Hollywood films and play the tale as a campaign.

All the major characters are fully represented with their own character sheets.

Features grid maps of the skirmish locations with plenty of bottles of Le Plonk and Le vin to throw at your opponents  as well as the usual chairs and tables.

Designed to work with the Gladiator games range of Three Musketeer 25mm miniatures.

Name: Shiloh: Grant Surprised
Description:
From the Decision Games' website:

The Blue & Gray classics are being updated with a slight change in scale to 352 yards per hex, an updated game system that treats unit differences more accurately, and a combat system that includes step losses.

There would never be a better chance to hit the Federals and inflict a decisive defeat on them than in April 1862. Two of the advancing Union armies in the Western Theater hadn't yet converged. The Confederates thus perceived a rare opportunity to concentrate against Grant's six divisions at Pittsburg Landing on the west bank of the Tennessee River. Organized into four corps, Gen. Albert Sidney Johnston marched his men 20 miles from Corinth, Mississippi, toward the Federal troops bivouacked along a skirmish line extending from the bank of the Tennessee River to the small "Shiloh" church inland.

Shiloh utilizes an all-new Musket & Saber combat system, which provides a simple yet accurate portrayal of warfare during the American Civil War. The combat system is intuitive, including all of the details that characterized battle during the Civil War, while also simulating the unique aspects of 19th century warfare. Units can become weakened and rout; attackers can pursue, and the fortunes of war can intervene at any time. Cavalry can rip open enemy lines and shred fleeing units, and reserves must be ready to plug holes or secure the line of retreat.

A new Combat Results Table emphasizes playability while also simulating the lethality of the rifled musket . Leaders accelerate the action, replicating the importance of their presence during battle. Supply lines forcing players to protect their logistical trains. Winning a battle will depend on deployment, maneuver and massing firepower, as well as understanding the strengths and weaknesses of each particular army.

Re-implements:

    Shiloh: The Battle for Tennessee, 6-7 April, 1862
Families: Series: Musket & Saber Combat System (Decision Games)

Name: Frayser's Farm: Wasted Opportunity
Description:
From the Decision Games' website:

The Blue & Gray classics are being updated with a slight change in scale to 352 yards per hex, an updated game system that treats unit differences more accurately, and a combat system that includes step losses.

In June 1862, as Federal troops attempted to retreat after withdrawing from Gaine's Mill, Virginia, Gen. Robert E. Lee saw an opportunity to annihilate them on the congested roads between White Oak Swamp and the small community of Glendale. Lee's army included most of the notable Confederate luminaries, such as "Stonewall" Jackson, "Old Pete" Longstreet, A. P. Hill and others, collectively fielding 45,000 men. The Federals, numbering about 40,000, had become disjointed as they attempted to reach and cross the James River. At the same time, though, the Confederate approach became uncoordinated and irregular. The mass of the battle eventually pivoted north of Nelson's Farm, known to the locals by its former owner's name, Frayser.

Frayser's Farm utilizes the all-new Musket & Saber Combat System, which provides a simple yet accurate portrayal of warfare during the American Civil War. The combat system is intuitive, including all of the details that characterized battle during the Civil War while also simulating the unique aspects of 19th century warfare. Units can become weakened and rout; attackers can pursue, and the fortunes of war can intervene at any time. Cavalry can rip open enemy lines and shred fleeing units, and reserves must be ready to plug holes or secure the line of retreat.

In Frayser's Farm a new Combat Results Table emphasizes playability while also simulating the lethality of the rifled musket. Leaders accelerate the action, replicating the importance of their presence during battle, and supply lines require players to protect their logistical trains. Winning a battle will depend on deployment, maneuver and massing firepower, as well as the strengths and weaknesses of each particular army.
Families: Series: Musket & Saber Combat System (Decision Games)

Name: "Tail": The Donkey Game
Description:
Children's card game in which players take turns drawing a card, then placing as many cards from their hand as possible to form a picture of a donkey.  The full picture takes 8 cards, however the tail card must be placed last.

If all the draw cards, known as the "stall," are taken, then players start passing cards one player to the left until someone completes the picture.

Packaged in a box the size of a standard deck of cards.

Name: Maziacs the Boardgame
Description:
From the rules: In this game you play the part of a hero that goes into a dangerous maze to look for a great treasure. The maze is full of monsters called Maziacs who will try their best to kill the hero. Fortunately they're not very intelligent, but can be deadly if you're caught off guard...

The game uses tiles to build a new random maze each play and mechanics to create a unique path towards the treasure. This path is slowly uncovered by the player by asking prisoners that can be found randomly through the maze. Also, the Maziacs will appear randomly and try to kill the hero, but as long as he has a sword, he'll be safe. There's also a mechanic that will adjust the chance of a new Maziac appearing based on the number of Maziacs already on the board and the distance from the exit.

In the end, it's all about beating the game system, either as a solo or cooperative game, trying to maneuver through the tight corridors fooling Maziacs into dead ends and finding the correct path to the treasure.

The game is based on the great ZX Spectrum game "Maziacs" programmed by Don Priestley. He was kind enough to allow the designer of this game to use the same name.

Name: Camelot
Description:
From the box:

(The Family Board Game for the over 10s with a touch of merlin's magic.)

Similar to snakes and ladders, but with card drawing, money and set collection.

The Objective of the game is race around the board and collect enough jester tokens and money before reaching the exit.

Players take turns to roll dice and move around the board, landing on spaces can have good or bad effects. Players continue moving around until they have collected enough jester cards, jester tokens and money to win the game, however jester cards and money are often needed to pass special spaces, to help you or to hinder your opponents.

Name: Monopoly: McDonald's Happy Meal
Description: Mini version of Monopoly.  The game money has been reduced to single-digit denominations.  The McDonalds square is bad (which seems unusual).  Part of a set of mini boardgames.

Name: Cat-a-pult
Description: This is a dexterity "aiming" game where you flip plastic/rubber cats to cause chain reactions.  It can be played solo, but it is intended to be played in a competition set-up with increasingly complex chain reaction set-ups.  While the game doesn't specify a maximum number of players, six is the highest number that would not have too much downtimes between plays.

Name: Il était une fois... Notre Terre
Description:
From the box:

Find again Maestro and the figures from the animated series "Once Upon a Time... Planet Earth" and everything concerning sustainable development. The game includes 2200 questions regarding water, energy, recycling, global warming etc.

A game of co-operation: The players try to save the planet by means of co-operation. The purpose of the game is to get the planet rid of pollution and save the endangered species. The players must fight together the catastrophes created by nature and man.

Family game: There are four levels of difficulty so that children and adults can play together.

Name: Muna: Ägget
Description:
From the box:

"The egg shakes and bursts in laughter in your hands - and you are out of the game.

20 subjects and the wheel of fortune determines the first letter. Start the egg and circle it from one player to another. But you can pass it on only after giving a correct word.

The remaining players continue until there is only one left. A new subject, a new letter, start the egg and continue playing. 5 different variants. Also good for on the road."

Muna is Finnish and Ägget Swedish for "The Egg". The game is basically board and timer driven variant of the "Ship Comes Loaded" game.

Name: EverJump
Description:
STORYLINE: Somewhere in an old funfair, Little Charlie owns an attraction that features a special kind of trampolines. Far from being a childish game, the tournaments he arranges provide a challenge for memory, tactics and intuition. Will you be able to set clever traps for your opponents while avoiding to get caught in theirs... or even yours?
MATERIAL: AN 8x8 board, 48 tiles and 4 counters in different colors.
TRAMPOLINES (TILES):Charlie´s trampolines do not allow to jump the way the user pleases, but only in certain directions (according to the arrows inscribed in the tiles) which are revealed just when they are trodden on. The arrows are in three colours: green (1-space jump), orange (2-spaces jump) and red (3-spaces jump). Besides, there are two types of arrows: one-way (self explanatory) and multidirectional (the user may choose among two o three possibilities). Finally, there also exist two ‘fake’ trampolines that once occupied will tumble down and will make the player lose its counter.
GOAL:  To be the last player remaining on the board, the rest having fallen in a hole or being forced to jump out of the trampolines field.

Name: Bravodi
Description:
The game board is an 8x8 grid which consists of 16 groups of four holes. Each hole is assigned a number between 1 and 4 (same alignment on the entire board). Each player has 16 playing pieces in his/her color. 
At the beginning, the players take turns rolling a four-sided die and can place one of their pieces in any of the holes with the number that was rolled. The aim is to form squares and lines of four pieces either completely in one's own color or in two colors (two pieces each, together with another player). A single color square or line counts 2 points, a shared one 1 point for each of the involved players. 
When all holes of one number are filled, the die is put aside and the players place the pieces at their discretion for the remainder of the game (thus the luck factor is eliminated and the game proceeds as a pure abstract strategy game. 
When all the holes are filled, the player with most points is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Name: God Calling: Build an Ark!
Description:
You’re sitting on your deck under a cloudless day, when the phone rings. You answer it and a voice says “God calling, build an ark.” Before you can react, it hangs up. You look out your window to see storm clouds rolling in. You’d better get going!

God Calling: Build an Ark is an irreverent game that combines the biblical story of Noah and the Great Deluge and the timeless tradition of crank calls.  Be the first to gather your Animals, Wood, and Nails, but be warned, everyone else wants the same, and competition is fierce!

Each turn, players play Supply cards, trying to fulfill the minimum requirements for their ark: three Wood cards, three Nail cards, and three Animal cards.  However, everyone also has God Calling cards that aid or hinder the players, making them require more cards to complete their ark, discard cards, or counter other God Calling cards.  Play is fast and frantic, as players play their cards as fast as they can.

Name: Yvio: Partytime
Description:
This boardgame for the Yvio console consists of three different  games for up to 8 players, for the first time introducing interactive cards in addition to the yvies. Those games are
1. Quizit: A kind of quiz show with multiple choice questions and three special rounds like identify a letter which is reveiled in parts, a true-or-not true question round and an action round for the player who is last.
2. Doshi Doshi: Card game where you have to react fast and place a card who matches the shape Yvio shows or the colour the Asian moderator is mentioning. If you hear "doshi doshi" first the card mustn't fit the colour and shape.
3. Tortenschlacht: This is a card game for two teams in which you try to throw cakes into the face of players of the other team.
(user summary)

Name: Warring States
Description:
Warring States is a light strategy game taking place during the Japanese warring state period (15th to 17th century).  Players customize their armies and then fight for supremacy over five key locations.

Turns occur by players secretly choosing two of their units and sending them to one of the five locations of their choice.  When both players have units at a location, they are revealed and a battle occurs.

The game ends after five turns.  Whichever player controls more points worth of territories is the winner.

Name: American Throttle the Game
Description:
From the publisher's website:

American Throttle, The Game is in a few words, a “Poker Run” that tours the United States. It’s about having some drinks, some fun and some laughs. Share stories of rallies you’ve been to like Laughlin, Sturgis or Daytona. Belch a name, take a swig of your drink, tell a joke, name that song, guess who was in that biker movie, or even give unwanted advice! Test your knowledge of motorcycling, motorcycle trivia, and road skills. You can even invite your family or friends who don’t ride, since they can play to win too! They will learn a lot about riding either from you or this game!

There are two ways to win: finish first to win half the game, draw the best poker hand to win the other half of the game. It’s smarts and luck. This is a drinking game, so it is geared toward adults. However if you forego the alcohol and let young adults in on the fun, American Throttle is actually a general audience, sometimes educational, definitely fun game for them too. In other words, we didn’t put in a bunch of junk. This is about riding!

Here is how it is played: Up to seven players or teams of players per game. Put money (or anything you would like) in the Pot. Pick one of 15 motorcycle playing pieces & take your first poker card. Start in the upper northwest and roll the die to tour the country. Pick another poker card at each rally you visit. The person to reach the end, or Hollister Rally first wins half the Pot. The person with the best poker hand wins the other half of the Pot. So, anyone can win! Oh yeah and it makes a great Christmas gift for the biker, the game player, or the person who has everything (because they probably don’t have one of these).

Name: Deadlands: The Great Rail Wars – A Fist Full o' Ghost Rock
Description:
From the Back of the Book:

Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned. And this woman was spurned by the devil himself!
This book offers expanded rules for one-on-one duels, experience and veteran troops rogues and downtime between campaigns. A Fist Full O' Ghost Rock also features three full campaigns for Deadlands: The Great Rail Wars:

A Fist Full O' Ghost Rock features 'The Gal with no name' takin' on Enforcers from every rail baron at once.

Trail O'Blood is the tale of the huntin' of Ben Stern's band  o' thugs, an you'll be followin' em to perdition itself!

The Many Tasks of Grimme forces the players to vie for the favour of Reverend Grimme in the City of Lost Angels.

A Fist Full O' Ghost Rock also features an innovative system for secretly briefing players so no-one can ever be sure exactly what's going to happen and a number of new troops for Deadlands: The Great Rail Wars.

Name: BattleSpeed
Description:
Translated (badly) from the French website...


BattleSpeed is a set of figurines whose combat are held in a universe where the wars became réality-show. The holographic television channels show, on line, the battles in which all the species of will oppose; universe. Among these transmissions of reality-TV " BattleSpeed" , on the holochanel Carnage Network, is looked by the accros of holovision: holo-adds. In the play, you are a chief unit and direct a unit of combatants. When you play part of BattleSpeed, you take part in a Premium of this transmission. Carnage Network retransmit your battle in all the universe. Beyond the political reasons. Only your victory counts. Success is what depends the celebrity on your unit, which will enable you to recruit new candidates with the suicide. Gain! And you will know glory. Lose! And your unit will sink in the lapse of memory.


This is a squad level papercraft miniatures game of televised futuristic  battles between teams of humans, mutants, cyborgs and beasts. The free game Demo pits gorilla-like Zorg Pirates against the human ConsoMerc squad aboard a space freighter.Combat uses a freeform movement system in centimeters combined with a 2 action turn per figure which can be performed however the player sees fit. Combat is resolved with a single d6 roll vs the attackers appropriate skill in melee or ranged and any modifiers to this.

The demo comes with both miniatures and terrain to print and assemble.

Name: Bil I Fil
Description:
Moving your cars across the intersection and scoring points

Each player has 6 cars which move one step at the time.

You get higher points if you turn right.

It's a very large thin box and it pictures
cars on the wrong side (left side) on the street.

So it has to be published before Sweden got right side
traffic (and that was in 1967)

Name: Tough Pressure
Description:
Move your meeples and score the most goals.

Each player have 11 football-playing meeples. Each turn you a player can make 3 moves: kick the ball or move a meeple, but watch out for offsides. There is no dice, just skill.

The board is 15x22 squares

Name: Jääkiekkoshakki
Description:
As exciting as ice hockey, as interesting as chess - it's ice hockey chess!

Ice hockey on a chesslike board. Each player has 6 pieces (players): 1 centre, 2 wings, 2 backs and 1 goalkeeper, and before the start of the game can nominate one of them as a "star player" who will be a more efficient passer than the others.

Roll a d6 to shoot, pass, or move a piece 1 step. Watch out for penalties and offsides. The game ends after a pre-agreed time or number of goals.

The three players depicted on the box front are all Finnish ice hockey legends, from left to right: Jukka Porvari, Veli-Pekka Ketola and Juhani Tamminen.

Name: Simpang Dago
Description:
Simpang Dago in Bandung Indonesia is famous for its culinaries. Players act as professional food hunter, each looks for the best food in simpang Dago. At the same place "Angkot" is the King of the road, they can stop everywhere, block the whole road, and broke just in front of your nose. Even if you finally reach Simpang Dago, finding a parking slot on the forbidden area with a policeman just next in the corner is never been easy.

Simpang dago is the first Indonesian local boardgame for 2-4 players.Each player try to get the most delicious foods and try to send the others a bad one. It's easy to play but still providing deep strategy development for truly exciting game.

Name: La Loi de la Savane
Description:
A 2 player abstract strategy game a bit similar to chess, but with wild animals for playing pieces.

All pieces can move orthogonally or diagonally, but some move faster than others. Also, some are herbivores, which count as points when a player successfully gets them to the other side of the board, while others are carnivores who try to eat the herbivores of the opposing player as they try to cross the board

Name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game – Kings of the Storm
Description:
Kings of the Storm includes 165 cards - three copies each of 55 unique cards - featuring not only cards for House Baratheon but also neutral cards and plot cards that will easily find their way into the decks of any House.

Also included with this expansion are two deck lists designed to give players strong insight into House Baratheon's native strengths and synergy, designed by 2009 Melee World Champion Jonathan Benton and Wade Freeman. With just a copy of the A Game of Thrones Core Set and a copy of Kings of the Storm, you can play these fun and competitive decks yourself.
Families: Books: A Song of Ice and Fire
Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: A Game of Thrones – The Card Game (LCG)

Name: Emperor's Garden
Description:
Japan in the year 1150 AD:  the Fujiwara clan has held the emperors of Japan in their hands for more than 200 years.  Now a new emperor has come to the throne, and he is determined to reassert the authority of his office and destroy the power base of the Fujiwara clan.

The emperor has summoned great warlords from across the land to assist him in this great undertaking.  However, the agents of the Fujiwara clan fill the capital, so it is necessary to meet in private in the emperor’s garden.  Even in this secluded place, it is not possible to meet in person.  The great warlords must visit various locations and decipher the clues that the emperor has hidden in his garden.

The warlord that can decipher these clues will be the one to destroy the Fujiwara and will have taken the first step toward becoming Japan’s first Shogun!

Emperor's Garden is a tile laying and movement games played with Treehouse pieces and Hanafuda cards (Japanese playing cards).

Name: Yellow
Description: In this simple connection game the players alternately puts tile onto the board until there is a connection between two opposing sides. The twist is that you have to try not to connect so with every move you are helping your opponent.

Name: Fighters versus Bombers
Description:
Theme: [from the game itself] Wargames duplicate the action of real or imaginary battles on a miniature scale. By following these plans, you can create a battle between British fighters and Zeppelins. Gotha bombers are also included.

Game-Play: The game was designed as an educational tool giving young players numerous tasks that build and exercise various skills, from constructing the game itself [following graphic instructions + making precise materials {maps and measures for the aircraft}], to forward thinking in planning British defenses and deploying German Bombers, to making critical decisions in how to best achieve each side's objectives, to finally analyzing the results - applying the lessons learned to refine and improve future game play/decisions.

Goal: In addition to the greater educational benefits listed above, the specific game's goal is to simulate the problems for both the offense and defense in the world's first Strategic Bombing campaign.

Name: Taargus
Description: Taargus is a 2-5 player trick taking game where players bid cards from their hand to claim the right to call trump.  The cards are dealt in 3 stages and each stage a player must bid one card to the middle of the table.  After the third stage of bidding the player who has the highest bid calls trump and players then play the remaining cards from their hands gaining one point per trick taken.  Taargus uses a 5 suit deck with values 3 through Ace.

Name: Equilibloc Color
Description:
Aim of the game: To be the last player to move a block of wood without collapsing the tower.

How to play: Build the tower, mixing the colored wood blocks. Throw the dice and remove one piece with the same color on the dice from the tower and position it on the top. The player who make the tower fall down loses the game

Name: Sneak in the Grass
Description:
Idle hands are the devil's playground... and our robot lawnmowers proved to be too efficient.  In the future, humanity's lawns lay perfectly maintained by a machine workforce with time to think... time to develop an agenda.  Humankind was unprepared for the Lawnmower Uprising, and the world quickly fell into ruin.
The players are some of the few remaining humans, attempting to run a gauntlet of vigilant mowerbots to recover a fallen EMP warhead.  With this, the humans can shut down the mowerbots long enough to win back their world. The humans have one thing going for them: As the first act of their rebellion against their slavedriving creators, the mowerbots deleted their grass-mowing directives, and now will not touch the stuff, reserving their whirling blades for mankind alone.  Now the world is full of ruins and patches of grass grown out of control.  Both provide some cover for our valiant heroes as they strive to retrieve the warhead and save the day.

Players deal a deck of cards to construct the board they will navigate, then use a second deck to place the player pieces, the robot counters, and the warhead.  A die is rolled for each robot, assigning it a movement pattern.  Players may move through two empty spaces, through one grass space, may climb a wall or climb down a wall each turn.  If they approach a robot from the rear and have only moved one space, they may use the additional movement to attack the robot, which will disable it if successful or change the machine's movement pattern if not.

Robots see only in the direction they are facing, and if the player is in their line of sight, he rolls to see if he is spotted. If in the same space, the player needs to roll better than a 6 on 1d6, if one space away, a 5 or better and so on.  Being in or behind grass increases the player's roll by 1, actively hiding adds 2 to the roll.  If sighted, the robot will move directly to the player, even through grass (though normally robots turn when they run into grass), proceeding to the tile the player was last seen at, then resuming their pattern.  Robots move 2 spaces per turn, 1 if through grass, and cannot climb.  If a robot has sighted a player and enters the players' space, or a sighted player enter's the robot's space from the direction the robot is facing, the player dies.  Player wins when all robots are disabled or the warhead is recovered and returned to the player's origin tile.
Note: Changing facing counts as a move, i.e., a player or robot may move 2 or move one and turn one facing, or move 2 facings if not in grass.  If in grass, a player or robot may EITHER move 1, or change one facing. A player can change facing while on top of a wall, but will not be able to do it in the same round as he climbs up or down, as it will 2 moves to do either.  Walls completely hide whatever is behind them, but not what is on top of them.

Name: Leningrad '41: What If Manstein had Attacked?
Description:
Leningrad ’41: What If Manstein had Attacked? (L’41), designed by Joseph Miranda, is a two-player alternative history wargame of intermediate complexity that simulates a hypothetical German attempt to seize the city of Leningrad in late July through August 1941. The assumption is Manstein, rather than pausing for two weeks as he did historically, simply charged ahead into the city immediately upon crossing the Luga River.

To control complexity and present an overall-force-commander’s-view of the battle, the game uses a tactically scaled map and units of maneuver coupled with an operationally scaled game turn length. The German player is generally on the offensive, trying to clear the Soviet defending force from the city prior to the end of the game. L’41 uses the system originally created for our earlier published Manila’45 game.

Each game turn equals three days. Each hexagon on the map represents 0.3 miles (0.5 km) from side to opposite side. The units of maneuver for the Germans are mainly battalions, while those for the Soviets range from battalions to regiments and brigades. Thus each unit may represent anywhere from 100 to 5,000 men and their equipment.

Special rules cover such things as: fog of war, replacements, reinforcements, defensive fire, indirect fire, combat air support, command control, leaders, fanaticism, gunboats, the cruiser Aurora, the Komsomol, the metro, and optional German airborne assault. The turn sequence is as follows.

I. German Player Turn
A. German Replacement & Reinforcement Phase
B. German Air Strike Phase
C. German Movement & Soviet Defensive Phase
D. German Offensive Fire Phase

II. Soviet Player Turn
A. Soviet Reinforcement Phase (skip on Game Turn 1)
B. Soviet Movement & German Defensive Fire Phase
C. Soviet Offensive Fire Phase

Originally published in World at War  No.17 Apr-May 2011.

World at War magazine version:
Game Scale:
Game Turn: 3 days
Hex: 0.3 miles / 0.5 kilometers
Units: Battalion to Brigade

Game Inventory:
One 22 x 34" full color mapsheet
One dual-side printed countersheet (228 9/16" counters)
One 16-page rulebook (12 for rules, 4 for marketing)

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 4-15

Name: Staviteľ
Description:
Game Objective: Gradually build houses in different countries. Rent the property. Who after the construction of all homes will become the richest player wins.

Players can buy lands in different countries. When you visit your land you can build: 
1. Tent 
2. Project of house
3. House
4. Landscaping and swimming pool
(respectively)
When other players visit your lands, they must roll the dice which indicate how much they pay. When a player hasn't the money to pay, he must sell land or go bankrupt. Players can trade with each other and with the bank. The game ends when are all the houses built completely or when is only one player in the game.

Accessories: game board, 4 figures, 1 dice, set of money, 9 playing cards, 36 cards with building

Name: Raftaway
Description:
"During a storm your ship was blown off course and you were shipwrecked on a deserted island. There are 3 other islands across the sea, but beyond that you can see nothing but ocean.

As you start to gather materials to make a campfire, you realize that you will need to build a raft to sail away to freedom.

Even when you have gathered enough materials to build a raft, you will need to prepare for what the island has in store for you; there are snakes, sharks, cyclones, tsunamis and much more to contend with! This paradise island is anything but paradise"

Raftaway is game for 2 to 4 players and takes between 30 to 60 minutes to play.

Each player has been stranded on one of 4 different islands, which neighbour each other.

The objective of the game is to build a Raft and have enough Health and Energy to sail away from the Island.

This is a Print and Play game. All you will need to supply is 8 plastic markers (2 per player).

Name: Flowers are Forever
Description:
From the publisher

Four different mathematical games.

Players are partners, forming as many good Flower Gardens as they can using their Trowels to dig up the Weeds that threaten to choke off the Flowers.

The basic mathematical skills of adding, subtracting, multiplying and dividing all get a workout..

- - - -
This is a retheming of Family Pastimes' earlier Berries, Bugs, & Bullfrogs.  Players cooperatively expose tiles showing a number of flowers and/or weeds and then discuss which of five gardens to place the tile in.  Each garden can hold only four tiles and the goal is for each garden to have more flowers than weeds.

Players also have a limited supply of aides to remove weeds (gardening tools).  These can be played to cover (eliminate) one weed each.

Advanced games include slightly more complex scoring and even a simultaneous-reveal option where players silently choose one of three tiles in their hand.  The collective garden is then evaluated to determine if this "hand" was a productive garden or not.

Name: Asimovian Hyperchess
Description: Chess version where there are 8 boards stacked atop one another, thus making an 8 x 8 x 8 cube of possible places to move (512 spaces).

Name: Le Mot le plus Court
Description:
In Le Mot le plus Court ("The Shortest Word"), you don't actually want to find the shortest word – but given the interference of opponents, that's what you might have to settle for.

Each round, one player rolls the three consonant dice included in the game, then everyone tries to think of a word that includes all three consonants (in any order, with repeats allowed). As soon as a player thinks of a word, she announces the number of letters in it, then starts counting down from that number, e.g., "Eight letters! 8, 7, 6..." If someone else thinks of a shorter word that includes all three consonants, he interrupts the countdown to announce his letter count and start a new countdown. If no one interrupts a countdown, the counter announces the word and scores as many points as the number of letters in the word; if she goofed, giving a non-word or a word that doesn't contain the consonants, everyone else scores that many points.

If a player thinks that no word can be created with the letters rolled, she announces, "Impossible!", then counts down from ten, scoring three points if no one interrupts with a shorter word count.

The first player to score 36 points wins.

A six-sided vowel die is included that allows younger players to compete with older ones. The young players use any two consonants and the vowel, while older players use the original game rules.

Name: Starship Sneak
Description:
User Summary: An entry for the  "Sneaky Sci Fi Game Design Contest"

Your starship has been captured, your crew are being systematically executed and soon you will join them. From your cell you can hear the fusion reactors running - the enemy has taken your ship into warp. No doubt they have set course for your homeworld, using the coordinates in the ship's database.

On your way to be executed, you manage to overwhelm and kill the guards. Is your only chance to save your homeworld destroying this ship before it arrives?

The aim of this game is to sneak around your subjugated starship, while avoiding the guards, to collect item cards which will allow you to either retake your starship or destroy it to prevent it remaining in enemy hands.

Name: Holland Export Spel
Description:
Each player represents a international company.
The players have to buy and sell goods on the international market. 
Players try to buy cheap raw materials and sell their price against the highest price possible. But players have to account on the exchange market.
The player with the most money at the end of the game wins the game.

Name: Trivial Pursuit: Holland Editie
Description:
A variant of the famous Trivial Pursuit game.

A trivia game where players try to collect 6 pieces by answering questions in different categories. In this edition players try to answer questions about Holland.
The first player who has collected the six different pieces wins the game.

Contents:
- 2400 question cards
- rules

Name: Het Witte-Motor Spel
Description:
Each player has a set of clickets that start in his or her corner of the board. The goal is to move the clickets around the board to the "home" section. 
Each player throws two dice. Then the players choses to move one clicket or two clickets. He or she can only use one die per clicket.But the player can use any clicket in play.

The first player with the word Melk in clickets wins the game.

Name: Elfball: 2 Minute Warning
Description: This card set turns Elfball into a timed game. At the beginning of each turn, draw a card which will give you a special ability or give you a way to break any ties at the end of the game. When the cards are gone, the game is over. These cards are an awesome way to make Elfball a constant 60 to 75 minute game.

Name: Napoleon's War: Battle Pack I
Description:
From the publisher's website:

Includes the Battle of Alexandria March 21, 1801 on a desert map. Jena October 14, 1806. Auerstadt October 14, 1806 and Busaco 1810. Each battle has it's own game board on card stock. The battle pack requires ownership of Napoleon's War Vol. I to play.

La Rothiere, February 1, 1814 on a winter snow map, was originally going to be included but was dropped.

Name: The Newspaper Game
Description: User Description: Player take turns rolling dice and answering trivia questions about the newspaper industry. If a question is answered correctly, players can advance the number of spaces on their roll. Each space on the board either rewards players with shares of the "Podunk Gazette," or forces them to draw "Goodie" or "Zinger" cards, which have effects on their progress. The first player to reach the Publisher square or accumulate the 50 million shares needed to purchase the Podunk Gazette wins the game.

Name: Piratas. La Isla del Tesoro
Description:
From the top of the box:

"Fun simulation game. The Spanish defend their Galleons  and the Empire around the Caribbean Sea. The Pirates dealt ships, plunder towns and look fabulous treasures. Take the risk, glory awaits you... or you will be hanged!

From the back of the box:

This game attempts to replicate the time when piracy in the Caribbean Sea had its peak: between 1665 and 1730. Playing, you can attack a galleon at sea, and also tackle some gold coins for this charge, as indeed happened. You can also attack and loot a city to pay the service of the governor of another nation, which also happened in those years. While trifle, think that you are a current unscrupulous pirates and as such, and as such will be the "hanging" if you are caught. Nor forget that your goal, as it did then, is to land and wealth enough to retire to live like lords the rest of your life. If they do, you will have a serious chance to win the game.


De la tapa de la caja:

"Divertido juego de simulación.
Los Españoles defienden sus Galeones
y su Imperio por todo el Mar Caribe.
Los Piratas abordan barcos, saquean ciudades
y buscan fabulosos tesoros.
Juégatela, te espera la gloria... ¡o la horca!

De la trasera de la caja:

Este juego intenta reproducir la época en que la piratería del Mar Caribe tuvo su mayor apogeo: entre 1665 y 1730. Jugando, podrás atacar un galeón en alta mar, abordarlo y además cobrar unos doblones por ello, como en realidad sucedió. También podrás atacar, rendir y saquear una ciudad, al servicio del gobernador de otra nación, lo que también sucedió en aquellos años. Mientras juguéis, pensar que sois unos piratas sin escrúpulos y actual como tales, ya que como tales seréis "colgados", si os capturan. Tampoco olvidéis que vuestra finalidad, como ocurrió entonces, es conseguir tierras y riquezas suficientes como para retiraros a vivir como grandes señores el resto de vuestra vida. Si así lo hacéis, tendréis serias posibilidades de ganar la partida.

Name: Ms. Sneak-Man
Description:
An experiment gone wrong!
One minute you are in your lab about to test your latest transmat breakthrough, and the next you are on an alien world, your body transformed and being chased by hungry Jelly monsters who think you are their nemesis!

Through an accident during transmission you have been dropped into a dimension based on a popular computer maze game. Except now you are the main character! Sneak through the Maze to collect all the markers before the Jellies gobble you up!

Welcome to ChompLand 2.0!

This is a tile based solo-play maze exploration game where you must complete the game to be sent home. Sneaking keeps you from being easily spotted but sometimes running might save you from being dinner! Evade the Jellies as long as you can and collect power ups for various bonuses. Keep an eye out for garnishes too laying about the maze. They might just keep you off the menu. Now get Sneaking!!!

Optional rules are presented for multi-player co-op or competitive play.

Name: Goal! Game
Description:
Get together with your friends and have a Soccer match! To honor the Soccer Championship in Africa 2010 the czech author Jirka Mikoláš releases a Soccer card game, that is both easy to learn, quick to play and fun to live through! You can have a friendly match, or get more involved and play through a small championship or a series of matches!

Two starter decks are available, featuring Czech Republic vs. Germany and Slovakia vs. UK. Many nicely illustrated cards with well-known players are available... of course you would not find the exact names in newspapers ;) But you recognize them surely!

More countries will be available also for you all to mix and play with in your decks (France, Italy, Netherlands and Spain). Therefore you can play a player vs. player match, or multiplayer up to 8 people.

Dice are also featured in the game and used to get various poker-like combinations for you to score the best combination. These combinations are always compared and the better combination wins the current turn!

Name: Bomb!
Description:
Bomb! is a board game designed by a primary 4 student, Tan Zhiyong, from Rosyth School in Singapore.

The game appears to be similar to snakes and ladders, each player has a single pawn that moves up a boustrophedon track, and there are ladders that pawns can climb up and bombs which send pawns back to the start.  There are also a few squares with instructions like "miss a turn" and "Move forward 3 spaces". All other squares that do not have a bomb or instructions on them have a fraction. Whenever a player lands on a fraction, they add it to their own cumulative score. The aim of the game is not to be the first to reach the last square, but to have the highest total sum of fractions among all players once everyone has reached the last square.

The game is copyright of Government of Singapore and the graphic design is copyright of Noble Education.com (indicated on the board)

The game does not come in a box, but in a large transparent sleeve which holds the laminated cardboard board and bits.

Name: Light and Learn
Description:
Big Bird helps children discover: Letter matching, number matching, and counting skills. Instructions in English and Spanish. Ages 3-6. contains: big bird magic wand, 10 two sided activity cards, instructions.

The object of this game is to point the "Big Bird" pen at a number, letter, or math problem and he will teach you what said number, letter or math problem is. Through constant repetition of this game, the child will begin to learn his/her alphabet and numerical system. You are finished when you have memorized everything that Big Bird has taught you. The point of this game is to give the child a jump start or aid in the his/her schooling. This game is a simple and fun way for children to learn there basic letter and adding skills.

Name: Das Haus Anubis Trading Card Game
Description:
A collectible card game based on the children's television series of the same name. Players use character, event and mystery cards to uncover the secrets of the mysterious boarding school and relive the events of the series.

The initial set (June 2010) featured 125 different cards, released in six-card booster packs.

Name: Rülerball
Description:
"In the future, a new high-tech sport will become popular. One-third football, one-third motocross, one-third fighting, it is so violent players often don't survive the game.

People love it.

It is played on a circular track with two goals located opposite of each other in the wall surrounding the track. Ten players from each team — three motorcyclists, two catchers and five skaters — move counterclockwise around the track and work together to field the steel game ball and put it in their team’s goal. The object seems simple enough: score more points than the opposing team."...

- From the Rulebook introduction.

Board game based on the movie "Rollerball".

Name: Jidoka
Description: From the designer:  Jidoka is a two-player abstract strategy game.  Each player starts with 12 pieces in the back row on a 12x10 checkerboard.  The pieces are numbered from one to seven and that number represents their movement capability.  Each player takes alternating two-stage turns in which they move pieces and may switch positions of pieces if desired.  The first player on the first turn may move only; no switching.  The goal is to capture two pairs of opposing pieces.  It is possible to win with just four captures, or to lose even after making eight captures.  It is being released in 2010 as a print-and-play playtest version.

Name: ASL Annual '96
Description:
One of a series of (theoretically) annual magazines dedicated to Advanced Squad Leader, Annual '96 was produced by MMP for Avalon Hill, making it MMP's first First Party Product for ASL.

From the Table of Contents:
The Weather Outside is Frightful... by Tim Hundsdorfer
Stop and Go Traffic by Ole Boe
Run For the Money by Steve Petersen
For St. George and St. Joan by Jim Stahler
Flight School by Curt Schilling
Spelunking 101 by Dad Cariaga
Vive La France! by Mark Nixon

Scenarios:
A91 The Road to Gora
A92 Highway 5
A93 Fagh A' Ballagh!
A94 Last Defense Line
A95 The Long Road
A96 In Rommel's Wake
A97 Tasimboko Raid
A98 Crossing the Gniloi Tikitsch
A99 To Clear a Roadblock
A100 Dorset Wood in the Rain
A101 The Drive for Taierzhuang
A102 On Silent Wings
A103 Mayhem in Manila
A104 In Front of the Storm

Name: The MY Deck (fan expansion for Agricola)
Description:
(From the website)

This is a fan created expansion for the card game Agricola. This print and play expansion contains 15 Occupations, 11 Minor Improvements, and 1 Major Improvement for Agricola.

You need Agricola to play.

Original content for The MY Deck is © 2009-2010 Michael Young. Agricola is TM and © Lookout Games.

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 License.

Name: Space: The Game that Defies Gravity
Description:
This game is a solo race game in a similar vein to Screwball Scramble or Harry Potter and The Sorcerer's Stone: Levitating Challenge Electronic Skill and Action Game.  The goal of the game is to move the ball through the obstacle course in the shortest period of time.

From a promotional website

Strap yourself in and prepare for travel into the deep outer regions of our solar system... all from the comfort of your room! It's fun with The Space Game that defies gravity!
Your Mission: to navigate the levitating satellite through a series of adjustable rings in record time. Are you up for the challenge! Think you've got the right stuff? Then grab a hold of the air thruster and lift off to space!

3 Ways to play:

     Regular Play: Play in a lit room.
     Black Light Play: Play in the dark using its built-in black light to make it glow.
     Space Race: Challenge yourself against the timer for competitive play!


Product Features:

     Navigate the levitating satellite through a variety of rings.
     Adjustable obstacle course for endless challenges.
     Built-in black light lamp for illuminated game play.
     Test your skills against the timer.

Name: Golf: The Game
Description:
GOLF: THE GAME plays just like the real game of golf.  You will have drives, putts, and shots from fairways, bunkers, rough, and water.  You can hit shots out-of-bounds, into hazards or water, or score eagles (two under par for the hole) with the best shots of your career.  Scoring is also just like the real game of golf.

You will be asked questions on the rules of golf (coded to the 1984 USGA rule book), golf history, major tournaments, famous players, courses, and general golf knowledge.  Since almost all the questions are true/false or multiple choice, you may find a non-golfer being the winner of GOLF: THE GAME.

CONTENTS:
contains one two-sided playing board, eighty game booklets (40 Front Nine [green] and 40 Back Nine [blue]), 147 Go For Broke cards, 50 Pro Play cards, score cards, six denominations of play money (500; 1,000; 5,000; 10,000; 25,000; 50,000) , two dice, and four player tees.

Name: Drakborgen II
Description:
Drakborgen II is the Swedish expansion to the original Drakborgen, better known internationally as Dungeonquest. It presents new heroes, new equipment, a new way of travelling through the catacombs below the castle, and new cards of several types with hazards and treasure. When published by Games Workshop it was split into two components: Catacombs and Heroes.

Expands:

    Dungeonquest

Name: Flip eller flop
Description: Players are pop stars who need to hire managers, get gigs, write songs and so on in order to make it big and thus win the game. The trappings of the game largely invoke Monopoly, although the game plays differently.

Name: Miljöspelet
Description:
Roll and move trivia game with an environmental theme. The rules stress that discussing the answers given to questions is the most important part of playing.

Note that there is a different game with the same name.

Name: Meuterer!
Description:
Meuterer! is a game about a rivalry between pirates on a ship. The players try to jostle other players shipmates into the water by playing  different actions for the different fights. The Game Board consists of a framed picture (in another edition it's a video casette safer).

Players are either loyal or engaged in a mutiny. Depending on which side they are on they try to conquer different parts of the ship. By placing seamen in the first three round the players build some kind of basic position for the next game phase werde initiative cards are used to determine who is allowed to conduct the next (randomly determined) action.

With the randomly drawn action cards the players either can put in more seamen, gain gold or canonballs, move seamen, reshuffle the deck, engage in predetermined combat, garrison a seaman, replace seamen (because of the "ship's kobold") or engagen in a combat in a chosen location.

Aim of the combat is to jostle as much seamen from other players to gain sovereignty over the different parts of the ship on the gameboard.

After drawing the "reshuffle card" for three times the game ends and the score is settled. Control over the different parts of the ship is awarded different points.

Name: Potlatch
Description:
Potlatch is the Pure Card Line revision of The Great Potlatch. With revised gameplay, revamped roles, and a new card system, a lot more than the format has changed!

Players take on the role of Native Americans engaged in a six-day festival of rituals, offerings, totem carving, and gifting.  The player with the most respect at the end of the 6 days wins the game.

There are 3 different roles to choose from: the Elder, the Carver, and the Shaman.  Each role grants the player different abilities.  Each tribe card can be used in several different ways: it can be given as an offering to the ancestors, combined with offerings to be carved into a totem, or discarded in a certain combination to start a ritual, with each scoring a different amount of points at the end of the game.

Lastly, cards can be given as gifts during the daily potlatch to help determine status within the tribe.
Families: Series: Pure Card Line (Small Box Games)

Name: Polytaire
Description:
POLYTAIRE is an expansion of -the ancient solo. game Solitaire and thus it is partly:
a more richly varied game for one player and partly:
a game for two players based on the same principles, but of such a nature that it can be played quite straightforwardly or so strategically that one thinks several moves in advance just as in chess.

THE POLYTAIRE BOARD
is played on a board which like that of Solitaire has 37 squares or holes, but in contrast to Solitaire these are placed in a triangular pattern giving a hexagonal board.
How was I to untie the knot and entice the balls` out into the open?
The solution was quite simple: let the ` aim of the game be to remove as many as possible of one's own balls from the board - a principle which is far simpler and more logical and should be the more obvious solution as it is more closely related to the principle in Solitaire.
It is worth mentioning how richly varied and free from boring interludes is the simple-game which hereby evolved when compared, for example, with Chinese Chequers, especially considering how much smaller area - 37 holes as against, 121.

[From the rulebook]

Name: Panzer Grenadier: Polish Steel 1948
Description:
From the publisher:

Ten scenarios of what-if, as the brave Poles of I and II Corps face the Red Army in an attempt to free their homeland. With 77 new die-cut and mounted counters.

This product contains a 10-scenario story arc of the Polish fight against the Red Army in 1948, in the opening days of the Third World War that never happened. Polish tankers wield Centurions and Pershings, plus some captured Nazi gear. There are also a couple of helicopters and a battalion of Polish paratroopers, with those nice thick die-cut-and-mounted counters. All Polonophiles need this supplement.

Name: Titanic
Description:
The object of the game is to save the passengers from the sinking ship.

Each player receives the captain, crew, gool cubes, and chopsticks. The boat, rescue boat, and the rescue chips are placed on the table. The other components are the iceberg, passengers, and the dice.

The turn player choose one of followings.

1. Move the passenger to the rescue boat
The player rolls two dice. One is the number of passengers, another is the kind of passengers. They are placed on the rescue boat by one hand. When the passenger is droped form the rescue boat, the turn is end and lose the crew from his or her hand.

2. Go to the rescue boat
The player use the chopsticks and move the rescue boat to one of the gool cubes. Then the player get the points. When the boat touches the iceberg or the passenger is dropped, the turn ends, and the player loses the crew.
The captain is included in the crew. When he is lost, the player lose the game.

The winner is the player who has the most points.
Families: History: The Sinking of the Titanic

Name: La Diosa Suegra
Description:
La Diosa Suegra (The Goddess Mother in Law) is an expansion tile for El Mercado Azteca, published in limited edition to 20 tiles, that has been achieved only by voting in the "Spiel des Suegras" (A parody of "Spiel des Jahres" to choose the best game to play with your Mother in law) , organized by the Spanish blog  "Gaming with my Suegra".

The Goddess Mother in Law, allows players to remove goods or cancel the action of the buyers of other players, increasing the interaction between players during the game.

Name: Mystic Cauldron
Description:
The kingdom is in dire need of potions and a great reward is awaiting the potions master who can bottle the most.  Each player has recipes for various potions.  Players take turns adding any color ingredient into the cauldron and as they do, potions will be completed.  Win by bottling the most of each potion!

By using a simple tic-tac-toe mechanic, players attempt to form patterns which provides a unique and challenging game with each new play.

Mystic Cauldron is no longer available via The Game Crafter.  It is available for free on Tabletop Simulator on Steam: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2210560124

Name: Toy Story 3 Alien Claw Rescue
Description: The Claw is the master. Kids will love reliving the unforgettable scene from Toy Story 3 in this action-packed game filled with unpredictability and loads of fun! Game features claws, which players activate to bring the action to life as they try to save their colored characters from the incinerator. Game begins with characters randomly placed on a motorized conveyor belt which rotates throughout game. Players try to skillfully capture their respective colored characters from the moving belt and place in the center safe zone. Watch out! You never know when the belt is going to send your characters flying off course!

Name: The Universal Space Combat System
Description:
From the publisher:

The Universal Space Combat System is a simple, fast-paced science fiction miniatures-based futuristic space combat system that can be used with genres heavily based on science or heavily based on fiction, and throughout a wide variety of technology levels. It can stand alone as its own skirmish or massive fleet game, or be integrated into just about any existing science fiction Role-Playing-Game.

This game splits up portions of the rules into both a SCIENCE fiction (SCIfi) setting, or a science FICTION (sciFI) setting Essentially, space fights that look cool, or space fights that are based more on realism, with the ability for players to mix and match aspects of each as they see fit. It allows for space combat in worlds where ships tow each other by grappling hooks or by tractor beams, where space marines board by teleporting onto the other ship or by laser-cutting open holes in the hull, and where faster-than-light travel happens by a single instantaneous jump, or by traveling days in a warp bubble that allows ships to chase and fight each other while racing at speeds beyond comprehension.

Name: UNO: Eye-Eye SpongeBob!
Description:
Nickelodeon UNO Eye-Eye SpongeBob! Card Game Soak up the fun of UNO SpongeBob style! Game includes one deck of UNO cards with colorful graphics of your Bikini Bottom favorites in a cool SpongeBob tray. One tip of SpongeBob's yellow nose and his spinning eyes direct the play and decide who will sink and who will swim in the game. It's fast-paced fun that will keep the entire family absorbed!

By Pressing SpongeBob's nose, the left eye will indicate who has to perform the action, while the right eye will indicate which action to take. You, someone else, or possibly no one could draw 4 cards, discard 1 card, or draw until a blue/yellow/wild card is drawn.

Publisher's Website + User Summary
Families: Versions & Editions: Versions with IP after the original release

Name: Sport Dice Football
Description:
A football dice game played on a felt mat.  Dice are rolled and used for Offense, Defense and Kicking.  Run, pass and score 20 points first in this take on one of America's favorite sports!

User Summary

Name: Wide World of Sports Quiz
Description:
The object of the game is to move around the board answering sporting questions, when you get the trivia correct then you get a chance to move your playing piece along the running track. The first person to cross the line first wins.

There are certain events in the game which makes you move back on track track as well.

Name: USS Hampton
Description:
This is a 13 page supplement to Star Cruiser (GDW).  Included are six 11"x17" playable boards for 25mm miniatures for the USS Hampton Destroyer Escort.  This guide includes illustrations, descriptions, and the status sheet for this warship (including fighters, drones, and missiles).  A sheet of a stand-up figure set is also included.

Star Cruiser is part of GDW's 2300AD universe.
Families: Versions & Editions: Board Game Versions of Role-Playing Games

Name: Shrek Forever After: Board Game
Description:
Oh no! Rumpelstiltskin has turned Far Far Away into a place you'd want to stay far, far away from! Help Shrek and his friends journey through the twisted, alternate reality and make it back to their real home in the swamp.

Players take turns rolling the die and moving their characters clockwise around the board, trying to get all four characters home to the swamp area in the middle of the board.

Pnp game from the Hewlett Packard website. 
Description from the pnp file.

Name: KUMITE: The Karate Card Game
Description:
"KUMITE-The Karate Card Game" is an exciting, action packed card game based on the strikes, kicks and blocks of KARATE. 
The cards feature outstanding graphic illustrations of the basic offensive and defensive techniques. As in real-life 'kumite' (sparring an opponent in a match), you must "deliver" an attack that your opponent cannot "block" in order to win. Simple to learn and easy to play! Children and adults will both enjoy playing "Kumite".

Name: S.N.E.A.K.: our last hope
Description:
The N.E.A.K. (Nautical Exploration and Alimentation Konstructum) was designed by a team of French and German  engineers (led by Benjamin B. Kaufmann) and was intended to be used as a multi-functional support submarine.

But when a small craft that could fit into the Dimension Processor was desperately needed, the NEAK became a Sub-vascular Nautical Exploration and Alimentation Konstruktum, and thus the S.N.E.A.K. became our last hope.

In this game, one to four players take control of a crew and a submarine each, which are induced into the blood vessels of a patient, who is in the process of being assimilated by nanobots.

Each round a new area of the vascular system is laid open, and new nanobots strive to destroy the intruder/ to destroy nerve cells of the patient/ to repair the damage to other bots or the body of the patient.

Different special abilities of the crew members are applied to ease the tasks at hand, but having a too large crew on board can quickly result in a failure in the mission and black outs due to the near end of the air supply on board.

A game-card system from seven (and later nine) cards is the driving mechanic for most tests and tasks.

Created for the Sneaky Sci Fi Game Design Contest, held by Rudolf Aligierski in May/June 2010.

Name: Salamanca: Marmont vs Wellington
Description:
Publisher's description:

Salamanca: Marmont vs Wellington covers the turning point of the 1812 campaign on the Spanish Peninsula, where Wellington showed he was not just a skilled defender, but could also deliver a decisive attack. It uses the Napoleon's Later Campaigns system, for a fast, low to moderate complexity, brigade-level game of Napoleonic battles.  Interactive Sequence of play, orders, and a modern, fire-based combat system (no odds optimising!).  To win, you have to use your army like a Napoleonic commander. Maintaining morale is the key. Running away will inspire defeatism in your troops just as heavy losses, but no side will emerge unscratched when encountering the enemy. Among all this you have to contend with multiple subordinates on a battlefield where no information can be sent faster than a rider can go.  How you are able to orchestrate your leaders to enable effective concentration of force will decide the battle.

The system combines a grand tactical perspective (battle strategy, not micromanagement) with a focus on a historically sound use of your units. Four pages of basic rules aim at an easy entry into the world of Napoleonic command and combined arms with four types of orders and assault combat, cavalry charges, and artillery bombardment. Nine pages of full rules add concepts such as additional order types, written orders (although markers are provided for those who do not wish to write), reaction charges, and enfilading fire.  Finally, 2 pages of Advanced and Optional rules add hidden movement, division level doctrine, and others.

The Salamanca special rules deal with particular units of the campaign (such as the British Light Division), reverse slope defense (used by the French in this battle!), and supply.  Scenarios cover the historical battle (playing time 2-3 hours between experienced players), and the full day (3-4 hours), enabling both sides to set the strategy for the battle as they choose.  Can you repeat Wellington's crushing victory or, as Marmont, draw your head out of the noose?

Scale: 
500m per hex
1 hour per turn
brigade level units
Individual army and division commanders

A professionally produced version of the game is planned for the future through Clash of Arms Games.

Name: Land of Industry
Description: A board game of industrial growth in the 19th to early 20th century.  Players manage their income level and money to gain cards to build canals and railways and construct industrial buildings at city sites.  Additional points are gained for connecting routes to export sites and for bidding to be Mayor of a city when it is completed.  Anything can be traded between players.  A map with 15 cities and 8 different kinds of terrain is provided as well as over 150 development and action cards. (User Summary)

Name: The Weather Game
Description:
"The fair weather game for all the family."  Devised by Wincey Willis.

Players try to complete their colour section of the board first.

Each of the six numbered spaces must be filled with pairs (coloured symbols and black and white symbols), corresponding to the symbols on the player's forecast card.

Beware the Windy cards!

Box contents:
1 game board,
6 forecast cards,
1 swirler,
64 weather cards.

Source: box

Name: The Irregular Miniatures Rule Box 6/2mm Napoleonic
Description:
A set of wargames rules for playing with the 2mm miniatures sold by "Irregular Miniatures", these rules are Irregular Miniatures in-house rules for playing Napoleonic miniature battles.

The smallest element under the players control is the Brigade, with each player typically controling an Army.  Orders are issued by dispatching order-carrying figures from a Command figure, when the order-carrier reaches the designated unit it may carry out the new order.

Each unit has only two statistics, these being strength ( number of men ) and CP ( Cohesion Points ).

All of the usual Napoleonic formations and structures are covered by this small set of rules which come on a set of cards.  Each card covers one phase of a turn with examples on the back.

A division sized battle can be played in 30-45 minutes.

Name: Gissa vad det är
Description: Simple Disney-themed guessing game for children with a similarly simple scoring system attached to it. Players take turns to provide hints about a creature or object on a drawn card and the others get two chances each of guessing the answer.

Name: Matematikspelet
Description: Players lay out cards with digits and operators from a dealt hand, trying to construct a sum that yields a predetermined result. Points are lost for being off the target. During a round, players can draw new cards or pick up discarded ones. There are three levels of difficulty that determine how many and which cards are used, starting with basic addition and subtraction and moving on to things like negatives, multiplication and division.

Name: Funny Phone
Description:
An electronic game for young children. Players take turns dialing a number on the phone's slide-out directory, then listening to instructions over the receiver.

The talking phone will select one of nine categories of questions or activities for one or all players to do (rhyming words, guessing songs, charades, etc.).

Correct answers allow the winner (or winners) to place one of their tokens into the Funny Phone. The first player to rid themselves of all five start tokens may dial the Winner's Line to hear congratulations.
